Strategy.text: Useful for strategy type of questions.
Goal: finalize all frameworks for PM design, strategy, analytical, and technical interviews; Practice in details 1-2 questions / day and schedule for mock interviews in phase 3.
Review interview frameworks and questions on How to think 10x Review System design questions
Framework to review & finalize: [Strategy] Tradeoff, new market entry, CEO-level issues and strategy, pricing
[Optional if strategy question] Strategy recommendation: for what to build in short vs. long-term
Mock interview: The following number of mock interviews are recommended for Google PM interview, which is one of the toughest out there.
At least 5-15 product design mock interviews
STRATEGY -It’s hard to have one framework for strategy type of questions.

Important note: One frequently asked strategy question is “Why is product X important for company Y?” You won’t find any framework for this question in any of the books, so I suggest reading and practicing questions to come up with your own criteria to evaluate why a specific product is important strategically for a company.
Evaluate different strategy: what’s the tradeoff
Suggest both short + long term strategy
Always evaluate: your ideas / calculation / strategy will always have loopholes.
So when doing tradeoffs between ideas / options, always discuss the general strategy and how an idea is good for the company & the users.
[Product strategy] Steps to take product to market

Think about the users first, always: PMs have to be user-centric.
I suggest going through all sorts of users you can think of, as well as different ways to segment users.

Question 1.question: What are some recommended resources for preparing for a product manager interview, and how does self-practice play a role in preparing for mock interviews?
Question 1.statement: To prepare for a product manager interview, sources recommend doing lots of mock interviews, both on your own and with calibrated PMs who have experience evaluating candidates. Self-practice plays an important role in preparing for mock interviews, with suggestions to practice 70-100 questions on your own, 2-3 times each in detail, in addition to practicing at least 5-15 product design mock interviews. It is also important to understand and remember key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview, such as those summarized in resources like the product manager interview book by Lewis Lin. Additionally, taking notes while reading good articles related to the company you are interviewing for may be helpful.

annotations.text: : understand and remember key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview

Question 2.question: What are some key frameworks and concepts to consider when answering strategy-related questions in a product manager interview?
Question 2.statement: There are no specific frameworks for answering "Why is product X important for company Y?" questions, but it's suggested to come up with your own criteria for evaluating the strategic importance of a product for a company. For product strategy questions, steps to take a product to market and designing product features are important concepts to consider. A framework for answering strategy questions may not exist, but it's recommended to practice and prepare for such questions. The book "The Product Manager Interview" by Lewis Lin contains interesting questions for a product manager interview. Additionally, familiarity with strategy frameworks would be helpful.

annotations.text: This document summarizes my approach to the PM interview at tech companies like Google and Amazon.

Question 3.question: How can a product manager think about user segmentation, and what are some ways to come up with new product ideas?
Question 3.statement: User segmentation can be a challenging task for a product manager. To make it more manageable, they should brainstorm different types of users and create meaningful user segments. Choosing the appropriate segment for a particular situation can be tricky. One way to achieve this is by researching user needs and practicing using frameworks like SCAMPERs, What if, and Oblique strategies to come up with modified products from existing products. In addition, the product manager should read many new product ideas and research new technologies and startup ideas in order to build up new product ideas. Going through various user segments is also a useful strategy for generating new product ideas. Finally, taking the product to market requires a well-developed product strategy.

annotations.text: What I wished I practiced earlier… (user segments & needs)
